raw_text:
Battered dollar hits another low
 
 The dollar has fallen to a new record low against the euro after data fuelled fresh concerns about the US economy.
 
 The greenback hit $1.3516 in thin New York trade, before rallying to $1.3509. The dollar has weakened sharply since September when it traded about $1.20, amid continuing worries over the levels of the US trade and budget deficits. Meanwhile, France's finance minister has said the world faced "economic catastrophe" unless the US worked with Europe and Asia on currency controls. Herve Gaymard said he would seek action on the issue at the next meeting of G7 countries in February. Ministers from European and Asian governments have recently called on the US to strengthen the dollar, saying the excessively high value of the euro was starting to hurt their export-driven economies. "It's absolutely essential that at the meeting of the G7 our American friends understand that we need coordinated management at the world level," said Mr Gaymard.
 
 Thursday's new low for the dollar came after data was released showing year-on-year sales of new homes in the US had fallen 12% in November - with some analysts saying this could indicate problems ahead for consumer activity.
 
 Commerce Department data also showed consumer spending - which drives two thirds of the US economy - grew just 0.2% last month. The figure was weaker than forecast - and fell short of the 0.8% rise in October. The official US policy is that it supports a strong dollar but many market observers believe it is happy to let the dollar fall because of the boost to its exporters.
 
 The US government has faced pressure from exporter organisations which have publicly stated the currency still has further to fall from "abnormal and dangerous heights" set in 2002. The US says it will let market forces determine the dollar's strength rather than intervene directly. Statements from President Bush in recent weeks highlighting his aim to cut the twin US deficits have prompted slight upturns in the currency. But while some observers said the quiet trade on Thursday had exacerbated small moves in the market, most agree the underlying trend remains downwards. The dollar has now fallen for a third consecutive year and analysts are forecasting a further, albeit less dramatic weakening, in 2005. "I can see it finishing the year around $1.35 and we can see that it's going to be a steady track upward for the euro/dollar in 2005, finishing the year around $1.40," said Adrian Hughes, currency strategist with HSBC in London.
llama3.2:1b: The US dollar has hit its lowest point against the euro on record after fresh concerns about the US economy were fueled by data showing year-on-year sales of new homes fell 12% in November and consumer spending grew just 0.2%. The dollar's decline has been exacerbated by pressure from exporter organisations, which have called for further falls in the currency due to its high value relative to other currencies. Analysts predict a continued downward trend throughout 2005, with some forecasting it could finish the year at $1.35 and continue upward for the euro/dollar.
llama3.2:3b: The dollar has hit a new record low against the euro at $1.3516 after data showed US home sales fell 12% and consumer spending grew just 0.2%. France's finance minister Herve Gaymard warned of an "economic catastrophe" if the US doesn't work with Europe and Asia on currency controls.
gemma2:2b: The US dollar has reached its new record low against the Euro due to concerns about the US economy's trade deficit and budget issues.  European and Asian governments are pushing for coordinated currency controls to weaken the dollar's value and help their export-driven economies. Data released this week shows a further weakening of the US economy with lower home sales and stagnant consumer spending, though the US government is allowing market forces to determine the dollar’s strength. Analysts expect further depreciation of the dollar throughout 2005.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The dollar has dropped below its lowest point since September 2007. The news shows that the US economy is facing problems due to high levels of trade deficits and budget deficits. Europe is concerned about this issue too. France's finance minister said the world needs to work together on currency controls, while other European and Asian governments have called on the US to increase its support for the dollar. In response, the US government is trying to let market forces determine the strength of the dollar instead of intervening directly. The euro/dollar pair will likely continue to weaken in 2005.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The US dollar reached another record low against the euro as concerns over the country's economic conditions continued.
qwen2.5:3b: The dollar has hit another record low against the euro following data showing economic concerns in the US, including a drop of 12% in new home sales and consumer spending growth of just 0.2%. France's finance minister warns of "economic catastrophe" unless the US works with Europe and Asia on currency controls. The greenback has weakened sharply since September due to trade and budget deficits, and is now trading at $1.3509 against the euro. Analysts predict further downward pressure on the dollar in 2005, with HSBC's Adrian Hughes forecasting it to reach around $1.35 by year-end and the euro/dollar pair to finish around $1.40.
opencoder:1.5b:
The text provided summarizes the following:

"Battered dollar hits another low" (concerns about US economy and trade levels), The dollar has fallen to a new record low after data fuelled fresh concerns. 

The greenback hit $1.35, before rallying to $1.3509. The dollar has weakened sharply since September when it traded about $1.20, amid continued worries over the levels of US trade and budget deficits. Meanwhile, France's finance minister has indicated that the world faced an "economic catastrophe" unless the US worked with Europe and Asia on currency controls. Herve Gaymard said he would seek action at next meeting in G7 countries. Ministers from European and Asian governments have recently called for strengthening the dollar, claiming the excessively high value was damaging to exports.

Thursday's new low for the dollar came after data showed sales had fallen 12% in November - with analysts suggesting problems ahead. The figure was weaker than forecasted rise in October. 

The US government has faced pressure from export control organizations which have been publicly stating that the currency is still at "abnormal and dangerous heights" set in 2002. Statements highlighting its goal to cut the twin US deficits have prompted slight downturns in the market. But many analysts believe it continues to be happy with the level of the dollar despite the steepening trend. 

The official US policy is that it supports a strong dollar but market observers believe it is happy to let the dollar fall because of the boost to its exporters. The former has let market forces determine strength, while the latter has urged them not to directly intervene.

Meanwhile, France's finance minister has said the world faced "economic catastrophe" unless the US worked with Europe and Asia on currency controls. Herve Gaymard said he would seek action on the issue at the next meeting of G7 countries in February. Ministers from European and Asian governments have recently called on the US to strengthen the dollar, saying the excessively high value of the euro was starting to hurt their export-driven economies. "It's absolutely essential that at the meeting of the G7 our American friends understand that we need coordinated management at the world level," said Mr Gaymard.

The US government has faced pressure from exporter organizations which have publicly stated the currency still has further to fall from "abnormal and dangerous heights" set in 2002. The US says it will let market forces determine the dollar's strength rather than intervene directly. Statements from President Bush in recent weeks highlighting his aim to cut the twin US deficits have prompted slight upturns in the market, but most agree the underlying trend remains downwards. The dollar has now fallen for a third consecutive year and analysts are forecasting a further, albeit less dramatic weakening, in 2005. "I can see it finishing the year around $1.30 and we can see that it's going to be a steady track upward for the euro/dollar in 2005, finishing the year around $1.40," said Adrian Hughes, currency strategist with HSBC in London.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about the US dollar's recent behavior, focusing on key ideas and details. Let me read through it carefully.

First paragraph talks about the US dollar hitting a new low against the euro after data shows house sales fell 12% in November. Some analysts think consumer activity is at risk. Then it mentions the US government is facing pressure from exporters who believe the dollar will keep falling into "abnormal heights" since 2002.

Next, it describes the US economic performance: consumer spending grew 0.2%, which is a bit weaker than expected and fell short of the 0.8% increase in October. The policy stance supports a strong dollar but market observers believe the dollar is still falling because of the boost to exporters.

Then there's mention of President Bush trying to cut both US deficits, causing some minor reversals, but most agree the trend is downward. The third consecutive year low for the dollar and analysts forecasting further depreciation in 2005. HSBC's Adrian Hughes says he'll seek action at G7 meetings if needed.

Putting this together, I need a concise summary that highlights the main points: continued decline of the dollar, factors like consumer spending data and export pressures, the government's stance on the currency, and analysts' expectations.
</think>

The US dollar has fallen to a new low against the euro, driven by recent economic data showing 12% year-over-year decline in U.S. home sales and weak growth in consumer spending. Exporters argue the dollar may remain weak due to "abnormal heights" since 2002. The government faces pressure from exporters who believe the dollar will persistently weaken. Analysts forecast continued depreciation, with the dollar expected to stay around $1.35, setting a track upward for both the dollar and euro in 2005.
tinyllama:1.1b: The US dollar has hit another low against the euro after data showed consumer activity and new home sales fell, sending it below a record low of $1.3516 in thin New York trade, before it raled to $1.3509. The dollar is facing further pressure as exports continue to underperform, with export-driven economies such as France experiencing "economic catastrophy" unless the US works with Europe and Asia on currency controls. Market observers predict that the underlying trend in the currency will remain downwards in 2005, with the euro/dollar expected to finish the year near $1.40.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Summary: The US dollar hit another low against the euro, as concerns over the US economy weighed on investor confidence. Traders shifted dollars to less-valued currencies, resulting in a dip below $1.350. France's finance minister called for increased currency control, urging world leaders to work together on this issue. Some analysts predict further weakness in the dollar and lower exporter earnings. The G7 summit is anticipated to address global issues and influence the currencies of member countries.
phi:2.7b: The dollar has reached a record low against the Euro due to concerns about the US economy and a call from other countries to control currencies. Weak consumer spending data released on Thursday also contributed to the fall in value. While some market observers believe the government supports a strong dollar, others say it is willing to allow it to weaken for its exporters. The Treasury Department has faced pressure from exporter groups who want the dollar's value to decrease further. The president has made efforts to reduce US deficits, but this has not led to any significant changes in the currency's value. Analysts predict that the dollar will continue to weaken in 2005 and reach around $1.40 by the year-end.
orca-mini:3b: The US dollar has fallen to a new record low against the euro after data fueled fresh concerns about the economy. The dollar hit $1.3516 in thin New York trade before rallying to $1.3509. The US government allows the currency to weaken as it supports exporters but some market observers believe it is happy to let the dollar fall because of the boost to its exporters. The US says it will let market forces determine the dollar's strength rather than intervene directly. However, statements from President Bush in recent weeks have prompted slight upturns in the currency. Analysts forecast a further weakening in 2005, with the dollar likely to finish the year around $1.35 and the euro/dollar rising in 2005.
hermes3:3b: Dollar reaches new low against euro, following US economic concerns (trade/budget deficits, consumer spending).
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The dollar hit a new record low against the euro, falling to $1.351 amid concerns over the US economy. France's finance minister urged the US to work with Europe and Asia on currency controls, while data revealed a 12% drop in November home sales and weaker consumer spending growth. The currency is expected to continue weakening, with some analysts forecasting it to finish 2005 around $1.35 and the euro/$dollar rate to reach $1.40 by year-end.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The dollar has hit a new record low against the euro, falling to $1.3516 before slightly recovering. Concerns over the US economy, particularly its trade and budget deficits, have contributed to the decline. France's finance minister warned of economic catastrophe unless the US cooperates with Europe and Asia on currency controls, urging action at the next G7 meeting. Weak US economic data, including a 12% drop in new home sales and sluggish consumer spending growth, have further pressured the dollar. While the US officially supports a strong dollar, many believe it is allowing the decline to benefit exporters. Analysts predict the dollar will continue weakening in 2005, with the euro potentially reaching $1.40 by year-end.
stablelm2:1.6b: The US dollar hit a new record low against the euro due to economic concerns such.. As trade and budget deficits continue to worry the US economy, ministers from European and Asian countries are urging for coordinated management worldwide. Recent data shows that the sales of new homes in the US have fallen by 5% YoY in November, while consumer spending only grew by 0.2%. President Bush aims to cut the twin US deficits; however, market observers believe it is happy to let the dollar fall for export benefits. A further drop of $1.09 is predicted in the dollar's value for the year ending 2007.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
The US dollar has reached a new record low against the euro, trading at $1.3516 before recovering to $1.3509. This decline, which began in September when the dollar traded around $1.20, is attributed to growing concerns about the US economy due to escalating trade and budget deficits. French Finance Minister Herve Gaymard warned of an "economic catastrophe" unless the US collaborates with Europe and Asia on currency controls, emphasizing the need for coordinated management at a global level during the next G7 meeting in February.

Economic indicators have shown a deterioration in consumer activity and spending growth in the US. New home sales decreased 12% in November, and consumer spending—which accounts for two-thirds of the economy—grew only 0.2% last month, falling short of forecasts. Despite official US support for a strong dollar, many market observers believe the government is content with its continued weakening due to benefits for US exporters.

Exporter organizations have advocated for further dollar depreciation from its 2002 highs, and President Bush's recent deficit reduction pledges briefly lifted the currency. However, most experts predict a continued downward trend in 2005, with some forecasting the euro/dollar rate to reach around $1.40 by year-end.
reference: The dollar has fallen to a new record low against the euro after data fuelled fresh concerns about the US economy.Thursday's new low for the dollar came after data was released showing year-on-year sales of new homes in the US had fallen 12% in November - with some analysts saying this could indicate problems ahead for consumer activity.The dollar has weakened sharply since September when it traded about $1.20, amid continuing worries over the levels of the US trade and budget deficits.Meanwhile, France's finance minister has said the world faced "economic catastrophe" unless the US worked with Europe and Asia on currency controls.The official US policy is that it supports a strong dollar but many market observers believe it is happy to let the dollar fall because of the boost to its exporters.The US government has faced pressure from exporter organisations which have publicly stated the currency still has further to fall from "abnormal and dangerous heights" set in 2002.Ministers from European and Asian governments have recently called on the US to strengthen the dollar, saying the excessively high value of the euro was starting to hurt their export-driven economies.
